ranked_diseases.explanation: Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that commonly presents with aortic root aneurysm and patent ductus arteriosus. Genu valgum can also be a feature due to musculoskeletal involvement.

Loeys-Dietz syndrome is another connective tissue disorder characterized by aortic aneurysms and arterial tortuosity. While patent ductus arteriosus and genu valgum are less common, they can occur in some subtypes.
Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome can present with aortic root aneurysm and other vascular anomalies. Patent ductus arteriosus and genu valgum are less typical but possible in some cases.

Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome is a connective tissue disorder with craniosynostosis and marfanoid features, including aortic root aneurysm. Patent ductus arteriosus and genu valgum may be present but are not hallmark features.
This condition shares some features with Marfan syndrome, including arachnodactyly and contractures. Aortic root aneurysm and patent ductus arteriosus are less common, but genu valgum can occur.
